title: Authorizes the department of health to establish medication and treatment compliance demonstration programs to assist persons with chronic health problems
summary: Authorizes the department of health to establish medication and treatment compliance demonstration programs to assist persons with chronic health problems; provides that services provided as part of the program and related administrative expenses that are not otherwise eligible for coverage under funding sources shall be eligible for reimbursement under the medical assistance program as long as federal financial participation is available; requires interim report to the governor and legislature on or before 12/31/2014 and a final report on or before 12/31/2016; provides for expiration and repeal of act on 3/31/2017.

    1    Section 1. Medication and treatment compliance demonstration programs.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2274

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
authorizing medication and treatment compliance demonstration
programs and providing for the repeal of such
programs upon the expiration
thereof

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Authorizes the Department of Health to design demonstration programs
to improve medication and treatment compliance. Services to be
provided and chronic health problems to be addressed are described.
DOH is made responsible for regulating the quality, appropriateness
and the cost effectiveness of the demonstration programs, and is
authorized to utilize all potential sources of funding.

Enrollment in programs is made voluntary, and participating
individuals are allowed to discontinue at any time without cause.

The Commissioner of Health is authorized to review and approve all
enrollment and marketing materials for demonstration programs, and
is directed to provide an interim report on or before December 31,
2012 and a final report on or before December 31, 2014.

JUSTIFICATION:
Unnecessary medical costs associated with non-compliant behavior of
patients have reached staggering proportions in today's health care
environment. Health care professionals have been continually
frustrated with the inability of many patients to follow through with
the medication or treatment regimen that has been prescribed. The
expanded use of home care has brought with it new and ever growing
complexities regarding compliance.

Non-compliant behavior has resulted in the expenditure of billions of
health care dollar's for preventable hospital and nursing home
admissions, physician visits, tests, and prescriptions. It has been
estimated that up to one third of the hospital and one half of the
nursing home admissions among elderly patients can be attributed to
patients not taking their medication as directed.

These demonstration programs will target approximately 1-2 percent of
the general population or 4-8 percent of the elderly population who
are using 5060 percent of all health care dollars. With concerns over
controlling health care costs, and the advent of managed care,
capitation agreements and other risk sharing arrangements, the need
to control needless over utilization has never been more evident.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
The Health Commissioner is authorized to utilize all potential Sources
of funding. The demonstration is made eligible for Medicaid

reimbursement as long as federal financial participation is
available. It is
estimated that a $4,200 annual expenditure per person for the
monitoring program can save $46,200 by keeping a patient out of a
nursing home.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately and expires on March 31, 2017.
